unnormalised: What are the key things to keep in mind when applying for higher education in India?
normalised: What are the key things to keep in mind when applying for higher education in India?

unnormalised: Applying for higher education in India requires careful planning and attention to detail. Firstly, prospective students should meticulously review the eligibility criteria for their desired programs. For instance, admission to IITs often requires a high score in the JEE Advanced exam, while medical colleges usually demand a qualifying NEET score. Keep track of important dates, such as application deadlines (e.g., 30/06/2024) and entrance exam dates (e.g., JEE Main on 05/05/2024). Also, gather all necessary documents, including mark sheets, identity proof (Aadhaar card no. 1234-5678-9012), and caste certificates, well in advance.

unnormalised: Secondly, understand the nuances of the application process for different institutions. Some universities, like Delhi University, might have a centralized online portal for admissions, whereas others, such as private colleges like Christ University, may have their own separate application procedures. Certain colleges may also conduct personal interviews (PI) or group discussions (GD) as part of the selection process. Furthermore, thoroughly research the ranking and reputation of the institutions you are considering. Consulting resources like the NIRF ranking can offer valuable insights.

unnormalised: Finally, carefully consider the financial aspects of higher education. Tuition fees vary significantly across institutions. A B.Tech program at a private engineering college might cost Rs. 2,00,000 per year, while a similar program at a government-funded institution like IIT Delhi could be significantly cheaper. Explore scholarship opportunities offered by the government (e.g., central sector scheme) and private organizations. Also, be aware of education loan options provided by banks like SBI, typically at an interest rate of 8.5% p.a.
